title: Cat. 69  Conversation under the Statue, Luxembourg Gardens, 1893
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 691893Way: 44  
Levy: 71  
Transfer lithograph with stumping, drawn on fine-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, lower right  
One state;  
image size: 170 × 154 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 15  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 41, 42, 86, 90, 98, 99, 113, 136, 137, 166, 249, 272  
Posthumous edition: 55 impressions printed by Goulding on 28 March 1904  
Posthumous watermarks: 18, 19, 37, 149, 199, 211, 219, 220, 289, 290, 300, 319, 322  
Stone: erased in 1904  
Whistler-Way Letters: 53, 55, 57, 58, 60, 62, 66, 70, 71, 72, 73, 77, 79, 80, 81, 82, 86, 111; apps. I.1, I.2, II.3, II.4, III.2, V.1  
Selected Literature: Pennell (1897), p. 288  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1894; Paris 1894 (no. 268, as Conversation—Luxembourg); London 1895? (no. 93, as In the Gardens—Tuileries); London 1895–96 (no. 4); London 1898? (no. 27, as Conversation); New York 1898 (no. 315, as Conversation, Luxembourg Gardens); Chicago 1900a (no. 139, as Luxembourg Gardens [Conversation]); Chicago 1900b (no. 40); New York 1901 (no. 142)

Conversation under the Statue, Luxembourg Gardens is one of three lithographs (cat. 68, cat. 69, and cat. 70) drawn in the famous Parisian gardens and sent to London in mid-November to be transferred and proved by the Ways (letter 55). In these drawings Whistler continued to experiment with the stump on fine-grained transfer paper. Here he used it to suggest the soft play of shadows and the effect of light filtering through the trees. The artist considered offering this image to D. C. Thomson for publication in The Art Journal in December 1893 (letter 71, letter 72, and letter 73). However, he suspected on the basis of earlier warnings from his printers that the delicate stump work might not survive the retransfer to additional stones necessitated by a large periodical edition. Eventually, in February 1894, he drew another image of the Luxembourg Gardens (cat. 81) expressly for The Art Journal.

At least twenty-six impressions of Conversation under the Statue, Luxembourg Gardens were printed during the artist’s lifetime, considerably more than T. R. Way’s (1905) figure of fifteen.

Chicago: AIC (2), ivory laid paper (314 × 193 mm), signed; ivory laid paper (311 × 205 mm), signed; MWC, cream laid paper (294 × 200 mm), signed. Glasgow: HAG (3), ivory laid paper (323 × 208 mm), signed; tan laid paper (310 × 201 mm); ivory laid paper (323 × 207 mm), signed. London: BM, grayish ivory chine (178 × 165 mm) mounted on white plate paper (348 × 256 mm). Washington: FGA, cream laid paper (294 × 200 mm); signed; LC, cream laid paper (310 × 202 mm); NGA, tan laid paper (324 × 206 mm), signed.

Remarks:Other impressions are found in Ann Arbor, UMMA; Brooklyn, TBM; and New York, MMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 69, only state. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.595.
